Member.description:
pll_bypass [26]
PLL clock frequency division bypass.

1: bypassed
pll_dsmpd [25]
PLL decimal division control.
0: decimal frequency-division mode
1: integral frequency-division mode
pll_dacpd[24]
PLL test signal control.
0: normal working mode
1: power-down mode
pll_foutpostdivpd[23]
Power down control for the PLL FOUTPOSTDIV output.
0: normal clock output
1: no output clock
pll_fout4phasepd[22]
Power down control for the PLL FOUT0?4 output.
0: normal clock output
1: no output clock
pll_foutvcopd[21]
Power down control for the PLL FOUTVCO output.
0: normal clock output
1: no output clock
pll_pd[20]
PLL power down control.
0: normal working mode
1: power-down mode
pll_refdiv[17:12]
Clock divider of the PLL reference clock.
pll_fbdiv[11:0]
Integer clock frequency multiplier of the PLL.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: an interrupt status register. It reflects the status of the masked DMACinterrupts. If certain bits of DMAC_INT_TC_STAT and DMAC_INT_ERR_STAT aremasked at the same time, the corresponding bit of DMAC_INT_STAT is also masked. Eachbit of DMAC_INT_STAT corresponds to one DMAC channel. When a bit is 1, an interruptrequest is generated in the corresponding channel. The interrupt request may be an errorinterrupt or a transfer completion interrupt.

Member.name: int_stat
Member.description:
Status of the masked interrupts of each DMA channel. Bit[3:0] correspond to channels 3–0.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated. The interrupt request may be an error interrupt or a transfer completion interrupt from a DMA channel.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_TC_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: a transfer completion interrupt status register. It reflects the statusof the masked transfer completion interrupts. The corresponding mask bitis DMAC_CX_CONFIG[itc], where X is the channel number ranging from 0 to 3. Theregister must work with the DMAC_INT_STAT register.

Member.name: int_tc_stat
Member.description:
Status of the masked transfer completion interrupts. Bit[3:0] correspond to channels 3–0.
0: No transfer completion interrupt is generated.
1: A transfer completion interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_TC_CLR
RegisterGroup.description: the transfer completion interrupt clear register. It is used to cleartransfer completion interrupts.

Member.name: int_tc_clr
Member.description:
Transfer completion interrupt clear. Bit[3:0] correspond to channels 3–0.
0: do not clear
1: clear

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_ERR_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: an error interrupt status register. It reflects the status of themasked error interrupts. The corresponding mast bit is DMAC_CX_CONFIG[ie].

Member.name: int_err_stat
Member.description:
Status of masked error interrupts. Bit[3:0] correspond to channels 3–0.
0: No error interrupt is generated.
1: An error interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_ERR_CLR
RegisterGroup.description: an error interrupt clear register. It is used to clear error interrupts.

Member.name: int_err_clr
Member.description:
Error interrupt clear. Bit[3:0] correspond to channels 3–0.
0: do not clear
1: clear

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_RAW_INT_TC_STATUS
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_RAW_INT_TC_STAT is a raw transfer completion interrupt status register. It reflectsthe status of the raw transfer completion interrupt of each channel.

Member.name: raw_int_tc_stat
Member.description:
Status of the raw transfer completion interrupt of each channel. Bit[3:0] correspond to channels 3–0.
0: No transfer completion interrupt is generated.
1: A transfer completion interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_RAW_INT_ERR_STATUS
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_RAW_INT_ERR_STAT is a raw error interrupt status register. It reflects the status ofthe raw error interrupt of each channel.

Member.name: raw_int_err_stat
Member.description:
Status of the raw error interrupt of each channel. Bit[3:0] correspond to channels 3–0.
0: No error interrupt is generated.
1: An error interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS
RegisterGroup.description: a channel enable register that shows the enabled channels.For example, if a bit of DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS is 1, the corresponding channel is enabled.The enable bit in the DMAC_CX_CONFIG register determines whether a correspondingchannel is enabled. If the DMA transfer over a channel is complete, the corresponding bit inthe DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS register is cleared.

Member.name: enabled_channels
Member.description:
Channel enable. Bit[3:0] correspond to channels 3–0.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_BREQ
RegisterGroup.description:
a software burst request register. It is used by software forcontrolling whether to generate a DMA burst request.When this register is read, the device that is requesting the DMA burst transfer can be queried.This register and any peripheral each can generate a DMA request.NOTE
You are advised not to use a software DMA request and a hardware DMA request at the same time.

Member.name: soft_breq
Member.description:
Whether to generate a DMA burst transfer request using software. For details about the request corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-64.
When this register is written:
0: Writing to this register has no effect.
1: A DMA burst transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.
When this register is read:
0: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] does not transmit a DMA burst request.
1: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] is requesting a DMA burst transfer.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_SREQ
RegisterGroup.description:
a software single request register. It is used by software forcontrolling whether to generate a DMA single transfer request.When this register is read, the device that is requesting the DMA single transfer can bequeried. This register and any of the 16 DMA request input signals of the DMAC each cangenerate a DMA request.NOTE
You are advised not to use a software DMA request and a hardware DMA request at the same time.

Member.name: soft_sreq
Member.description:
Whether to generate a DMA single transfer request using software. For details about the request signal corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-64.
When this register is written:
0: Writing to this register has no effect.
1: A DMA single transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.
When this register is read:
0: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] do not send a DMA single request.
1: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] is requesting a DMA single transfer.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_LBREQ
RegisterGroup.description: a software last burst request register. It is used by software forcontrolling whether to generate a DMA last burst transfer request.

Member.name: soft_lbreq
Member.description:
Last burst request initiated by software. For details about the request signal corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-64.
0: no effect
1: A DMA last burst transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_LSREQ
RegisterGroup.description: a software last single request register. It is used by software forcontrolling whether to generate a DMA last single transfer request.

Member.name: soft_lsreq
Member.description:
Last single transfer request initiated by software. For the request corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-64.
0: no effect
1: The last DMA single transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CONFIG
RegisterGroup.description:
a DMAC configuration register. You can change the endianness modes ofthe two master interfaces of the DMAC by writing to m1 (bit[1]) and m2 (bit[2]) in thisregister. After reset, the modes of the two master interfaces are set to little-endian mode.NOTE
Both masters work in little-endian mode.

Member.name: m2
Member.description:
Endianness mode of master 2.
0: little-endian mode
1: big-endian mode

Member.name: m1
Member.description:
Endianness mode of master 1.
0: little-endian mode
1: big-endian mode

Member.name: e
Member.description:
DMAC enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SYNC
RegisterGroup.description: a synchronization register. It is used to enable or disable thesynchronization logic provided for DMA request signals.

Member.name: dmac_sync
Member.description:
Enable for the DMA request signal synchronization logic of the corresponding peripheral. For details about the request corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-64.
0: enabled
1: disabled

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CX_SRC_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description:
a source address register. It shows the source addresses (sortedby byte) of the data to be transmitted.Its offset address is 0x100 + X x 0x20. The value of X ranges from 0 to 3. The values 0–3correspond to DMA channels 0–3.Before a channel is enabled, its corresponding register must be programmed by usingsoftware. After the channel is enabled, the register is updated in any of the following cases:
  • The source address is incremented.
  • A complete data block is transferred and then loaded from LLI nodes.If a channel is active, no valid information is obtained when this register is read. This isbecause after software obtains the register value, the value changes during data transfer.Therefore, the register is read after the channel stops data transfer. At this time, the read valueis the last source address read by the DMAC.The source and destination addresses must be aligned with the transfer widths of the sourceand destination devices.

Member.name: src_addr
Member.description: DMA source address.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CX_DEST_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description:
a destination address register. Its offset address is 0x104 + X x0x20. The value of X ranges from 0 to 3. The values 0–3 correspond to DMA channels 0–3.This register contains the destination addresses (sorted by byte) of the data to be transferred.Before a channel is enabled, its corresponding register must be programmed by usingsoftware. After the channel is enabled, the register is updated in any of the following cases:
  • The destination address is incremented.
  • A complete data block is transferred and then loaded from LLI nodes.If a channel is active, no valid information is obtained when this register is read. This isbecause after software obtains the register value, the value changes during data transfer.Therefore, the register is read after the channel stops data transfer. At this time, the read valueis the last destination address written by the DMAC.

Member.name: dest_addr
Member.description: DMA destination address.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CXLLI
RegisterGroup.description:
an LLI register. Its offset address is 0x108 + X x 0x20. The value of Xranges from 0 to 3. The values 0–3 correspond to DMA channels 0–3.The following is the data structure of a DMAC LLI node:
  • DMAC_CX_SRC_ADDR. It is used to set the start address for the source device.
  • DMAC_CX_DEST_ADDR. It is used to set the start address for the destination device.
  • DMAC_CXLLI. It is used to set the address for the next node.
  • DMAC_CX_CONTROL. It sets the masters, data widths, burst sizes, address incrementmodes, and transfer sizes of the source and destination devices.Data structure of a DMAC LLI node
CAUTIONThe LLI field value must be less than or equal to 0xFFFF_FFF0. Otherwise, the addressis wrapped to 0x0000_0000 during a 4-word burst transfer. As a result, the data structure ofLLI nodes cannot be stored in a consecutive address area.If the LLI field is set to 0, the current node is at the end of the linked list. In this case, thecorresponding channel is disabled after data blocks corresponding to the current node aretransferred.

Member.name: lli
Member.description: LLI. Bit[31:2] in the next LLI node address and the address bit[1:0] are set to 0. A linked list address must be 4-byte aligned.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. This bit value must be 0 in writes and must be masked in reads.

Member.name: lm
Member.description:
Master for loading the next LLI node.
0: master 1
1: master 2

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CX_CONTROL
RegisterGroup.description: a channel control register. Its offset address is 0x10C + X x 0x20.The value of X ranges from 0 to 3. The values 0–3 correspond to DMA channels 0–3.This register contains the control information about the DMA channels, such as the transfersize, burst size, and transfer bit width.Before a channel is enabled, its corresponding register must be programmed by usingsoftware. After the channel is enabled, the register value is updated when being loaded from alinked list node after a complete data block is transferred.If a channel is active, no valid information is obtained when this register is read. This isbecause after software obtains the register value, the value changes during data transfer.Therefore, the register can be read after the channel stops data transfer.

Member.name: i
Member.description:
Transfer completion interrupt enable. This bit determines whether the current LLI node triggers a transfer completion interrupt.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: prot
Member.description: HPROT[2:0] access protection signal transmitted by the master.

Member.name: di
Member.description:
Destination address increment.
0: The destination address is not incremented.
1: The destination address is incremented once after a data segment is transferred.
If the destination device is a peripheral, the destination address is not incremented. If the destination device is a memory, the destination address is incremented.

Member.name: si
Member.description:
Source address increment.
0: The source address is not incremented.
1: The source address is incremented once after a data segment is transferred.
If the source device is a peripheral, the source address is not incremented. If the source device is a memory, the source address is incremented.

Member.name: d
Member.description:
Master for accessing the destination device.
0: The SPDIF, SIO 0, SIO 1, UART 0, UART 1, and SCI access the destination device by using master 1.
1: The SPI flash, NAND flash, NOR flash, and DDRC access the destination device by using master 2.

Member.name: s
Member.description:
Master for accessing the source device.
0: The SPDIF, SIO 0, SIO 1, UART 0, UART 1, and SCI access the source device by using master 1.
1: The SPI flash, NAND flash, NOR flash, and DDRC access the source device by using master 2.

Member.name: dwidth
Member.description:
Transfer bit width of the destination device.
The transfer bit width is invalid if it is greater than the bit width of the master.
The data widths of the destination and source devices can be different. Hardware automatically packs and unpacks the data.
For the mapping between the value of DWidth and the bit width, see Table 3-67.

Member.name: swidth
Member.description:
Transfer bit width of the source device.
The transfer bit width is invalid if it is greater than the bit width of the master.
The data widths of the destination and source devices can be different. Hardware automatically packs and unpacks the data.
For the mapping between the value of SWidth and the bit width, see Table 3-67.

Member.name: dbsize
Member.description:
Burst size of the destination device.
Number of data segments to be transferred by the destination device in a burst transfer, that is, the number of transferred data segments when DMACCxBREQ is valid.
This value must be set to a burst size supported by the destination device. If the destination device is a memory, the value is set to the storage area size beyond the storage address boundary.
For the mapping between the value of DBSize and the transfer size, see Table 3-66.

Member.name: sbsize
Member.description:
Burst size of the source device.
Number of data segments to be transferred by the source device in a burst transfer, that is, the number of transferred data segments when DMACCxBREQ is valid.
The value must be set to a burst size supported by the source device. If the source device is a memory, the value is set to the storage area size beyond the storage address boundary.
For the mapping between the value of SBSize and the transfer size, see Table 3-66.

Member.name: transfersize
Member.description:
The DMA transfer size can be configured by writing to this register only when the DMAC is a flow controller. This field indicates the amount of data to be transferred by the source device.
When this register is read, the amount of data transferred over the bus connected to the destination device is obtained.
If a channel is active, no valid information is obtained when this register is read. This is because after software obtains the register value, the value changes during data transfer. Therefore, the register is read after the channel is enabled and data transfer stops.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CX_CONFIG
RegisterGroup.description: a channel configuration register. Its offset address is 0x110 + X x0x20. The value of X ranges from 0 to 3. The values 0–3 correspond to DMA channels 0–3.This register is not updated when a new linked list node is loaded.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
This field must be 0 in writes and must be masked in reads.

Member.name: h
Member.description:
Halt bit.
0: DMA requests are allowed.
1: The subsequent DMA requests are ignored, and all data in the channel FIFO is transferred.
This bit can disable a DMA channel without data loss by working with the Active bit and the Channel Enable bit.

Member.name: a
Member.description:
Active bit.
0: There is no data in the channel FIFO.
1: There is data in the channel FIFO.
This bit can disable a DMA channel without data loss by working with the Halt bit and Channel Enable bit.

Member.name: l
Member.description:
Lock bit.
0: Lock transfer on the bus is disabled.
1: Lock transfer on the bus is enabled.

Member.name: itc
Member.description:
Transfer completion interrupt mask for the current channel.
0: masked
1: not masked

Member.name: ie
Member.description:
Transfer error interrupt mask for the current channel.
0: masked
1: not masked

Member.name: flow_cntrl
Member.description:
Flow control and transfer type.
This field specifies the flow controller and transfer type. The flow controller can be the DMAC, source device, or destination device.
The transfer type can be memory to peripheral, peripheral to memory, peripheral to peripheral, or memory to memory. For details, see xx.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
This bit value must be 0 during write operations, and this bit must be masked during read operations.

Member.name: dest_peripheral
Member.description:
Destination device. The field is used to select a peripheral request signal as the request signal for the DMA destination device of the channel.
If the destination device for DMA transfer is a memory, this field is ignored.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
This bit value must be 0 during write operations, and this bit must be masked during read operations.

Member.name: src_peripheral
Member.description:
Source device. This field is used to select a peripheral request signal as the request signal for the DMA source device of the channel.
If the source device for DMA transfer is a memory, this field is ignored.

Member.name: e
Member.description:
Channel enable. The current status of a channel can be queried by reading this register.
0: disabled
1: enabled
Clearing this bit can disable a channel. When this bit is cleared, the current bus transfer continues until the data transfer is complete. Then, the channel is disabled and the remaining data in the FIFO is lost. When the last linked list node is transferred or an error occurs during transfer, the channel is also disabled and this bit is cleared. If you want to disable a channel without data loss, the Halt bit must be set to 1 so the subsequent DMA requests are ignored by the channel. After this, the Active bit must be polled until its value becomes 0, indicating that there is no data in the channel FIFO. At this time, the Enable bit can be cleared.
To enable a channel by setting this bit to 1, you must reinitialize the channel. If a channel is enabled by setting this bit to 1 only, unexpected results may occur.

Control word for backward calibration.

bcal[1: 0] = 01: Calibration stops but calibration signals are still generated.
bcal[1:0] = 10: invalid
bcal[1:0] = 11: Calibration stops and no calibration signal is generated.

Member.name: endoutz

Data output enable.

0: output normal data

Member.name: endcr

Member.name: chsel
Member.description:
Output timing format

1: data from both channel I and channel Q

Member.name: ppsel
Member.description: Ping pong mode enable, active high.

Member.name: use_prev_f
Member.description:

Member.name: opm

0: default

RegisterGroup.name: SC_LOCKEN
RegisterGroup.description:
a write protection control register. This register provides the write protectionmechanism for the following key registers of the system controller:
  • SC_CTRLSC_SYSRESWhen 0x4F50_454E is written to SC_LOCKEN, the write protection function of thepreceding key registers is disabled and their attributes are changed to write. Then theseregisters can be written. When any value but not 0x4F50_454E is written to SC_LOCKEN,the attributes of these registers are changed to read-only. Then writing to these registers has noeffect.You can check whether write protection is enabled for the key registers by readingSC_LOCKEN. For example:
  • If the value 0x756E_4C4F is returned after SC_LOCKEN is read, write protection isdisabled, and the key registers can be written.
  • If the value 0x4C4F_434B is returned, write protection is enabled, and writing to the keyregisters has no effect.The reset value of SC_LOCKEN is 0x756E_4C4F, indicating that write protection is disabledfor the key registers.

Member.name: sc_locken
Member.description: Write protection indicator of key system registers. For details, see the function description of SC_LOCKEN.

RegisterGroup.name: SC_SYSID
RegisterGroup.description: a chip ID register.

Member.name: sc_sysid
Member.description: Major release of the chip.

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER0_LOAD
RegisterGroup.description:
an initial count value register. It is used to set the initial count value ofeach timer. Each timer (timers 0–9) has such a register.When a timer is in periodic mode and the count value decreases to 0, the value ofTIMERx_LOAD is reloaded to the counter. When a value is written to TIMERx_LOAD, thevalue of the current counter is changed to the written value on the next rising edge of theTIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx.NOTE
  • The minimum valid value written to TIMERx_LOAD is 1.
  • When 0 is written to TIMERx_LOAD, the dual-timer submodule immediately generates an interrupt.When a value is written to TIMERx_BGLOAD, the value of TIMERx_LOAD is overwritten,but the current value of the timer is retained.If values are written to TIMERx_BGLOAD and TIMERx_LOAD before the rising edge ofTIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx is reached, the value of the counter on the next risingedge is changed to the written value of TIMERx_LOAD. From then on, when the counterreaches 0, the last value written to TIMERx_BGLOAD or TIMERx_LOAD is reloaded.When TIMERx_BGLOAD and TIMERx_LOAD are written twice respectively, thevalue written to TIMERx_BGLOAD is returned after TIMERx_LOAD is read.

Member.name: timer0_load
Member.description: Initial count value of timer 0.

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER1_LOAD
RegisterGroup.description:
an initial count value register. It is used to set the initial count value ofeach timer. Each timer (timers 0–9) has such a register.
When a timer is in periodic mode and the count value decreases to 0, the value ofTIMERx_LOAD is reloaded to the counter. When a value is written to TIMERx_LOAD, thevalue of the current counter is changed to the written value on the next rising edge of theTIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx.
NOTE

  • The minimum valid value written to TIMERx_LOAD is 1.
  • When 0 is written to TIMERx_LOAD, the dual-timer submodule immediately generates an interrupt.

When a value is written to TIMERx_BGLOAD, the value of TIMERx_LOAD is overwritten,but the current value of the timer is retained.
If values are written to TIMERx_BGLOAD and TIMERx_LOAD before the rising edge ofTIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx is reached, the value of the counter on the next risingedge is changed to the written value of TIMERx_LOAD. From then on, when the counterreaches 0, the last value written to TIMERx_BGLOAD or TIMERx_LOAD is reloaded.
When TIMERx_BGLOAD and TIMERx_LOAD are written twice respectively, thevalue written to TIMERx_BGLOAD is returned after TIMERx_LOAD is read.

Member.name: timer1_load
Member.description: Initial count value of timer 1.

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER0_VALUE
RegisterGroup.description:
a current count value register. It provides the current value of the counterthat is counting down.Each timer (timers 0–9) has such a register.After a value is written to TIMERx_LOAD, TIMERx_VALUE immediately shows the newlyloaded value of the counter in the PCLK domain without waiting for the next TIMCLK clockedge enabled by TIMCLKENx.NOTE
When a timer is in 16-bit mode, the upper 16 bits of the 32-bit TIMERx_VALUE register are notautomatically set to 0. If TIMERx_LOAD is never written after the timer is switched from 32-bit modeto 16-bit mode, the upper 16 bits of TIMER0_VALUE may be non-zero values.

Member.name: timer0_value
Member.description: Current count value of timer 0 that is counting down.

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER1_VALUE
RegisterGroup.description:
a current count value register. It provides the current value of the counterthat is counting down.
Each timer (timers 0–9) has such a register.
After a value is written to TIMERx_LOAD, TIMERx_VALUE immediately shows the newlyloaded value of the counter in the PCLK domain without waiting for the next TIMCLK clockedge enabled by TIMCLKENx.
NOTE

When a timer is in 16-bit mode, the upper 16 bits of the 32-bit TIMERx_VALUE register are notautomatically set to 0. If TIMERx_LOAD is never written after the timer is switched from 32-bit modeto 16-bit mode, the upper 16 bits of TIMER0_VALUE may be non-zero values.

Member.name: timer0_value
Member.description: Current count value of timer 1 that is counting down.

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER0_CONTROL
RegisterGroup.description:
a timer control register. Each timer (timers 0–9) has such a register.NOTE
When the periodic mode is selected, TIMERx_CONTROL[timermode] must be set to 1, andTIMERx_CONTROL[oneshot] must be set to 0.

Member.name: timeren
Member.description:
Timer enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.description:
Timer count mode.
0: free-running mode
1: periodic mode

Member.name: intenable
Member.description:
TIMERx_RIS interrupt mask.
0: masked

Member.name: timerpre
Member.description:
Timer prescaling divider.
00: no prescaling. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is used.
01: 4-level prescaling. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 16.
10: 8-level prescaling. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 256.
11: undefined. If this field is set to 11, 8-level prescaling is used, which indicates that the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 256.

Member.name: timersize
Member.description:
Counter operating mode.
0: 16-bit mode
1: 32-bit mode

Member.name: oneshot
Member.description:
Count mode.
0: periodic mode or free-running mode
1: one-shot mode

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER0_BGLOAD
RegisterGroup.description: an initial count value register in periodic mode. Each timer (timers0?9) has such a register.This register contains the initial count value of the timer. In periodic mode, this register isused to reload an initial count value when the count value of the timer reaches 0.The register also provides another method of accessing TIMERx_LOAD. After a valueis written to TIMERx_BGLOAD, the timer, however, does not count starting from thenewly written value immediately.

Member.description:
Initial count value of timer 0.
Note: This register differs from TIMERx_LOAD. For details, see the description of TIMERX_LOAD.

In periodic mode, this register isused to reload an initial count value when the count value of the timer reaches 0.The register also provides another method of accessing TIMERx_LOAD. After a valueis written to TIMERx_BGLOAD, the timer, however, does not count starting from thenewly written value immediately.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_LOAD
RegisterGroup.description: an initial count value register. It is used to configure the initial count valuefor the internal counter of the watchdog.

Member.name: wdg_load
Member.description: Initial count value.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_VALUE
RegisterGroup.description: a current count value register. It is used to read the current count value ofthe internal counter of the watchdog.

Member.name: wdogvalue
Member.description: Current count value of the watchdog counter.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_CONTROL
RegisterGroup.description: a control register. It is used to enable or disable the watchdog, andcontrol the interrupt and reset functions.

Member.name: resen
Member.description:
Reset output enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: inten
Member.description:
Interrupt output enable.
0: The counter stops counting, the current count value is retained, and the watchdog is disabled.
1: The counter, interrupt, and watchdog are enabled.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_INTCLR
RegisterGroup.description: an interrupt clear register. It is used to clear watchdog interrupts sothe watchdog can reload an initial value for counting. This register is write-only. When avalue is written to this register, the watchdog interrupts are cleared. No written value isrecorded in this register and no default reset value is defined.

Member.name: wdg_intclr
Member.description: Writing any value to this register clears the watchdog interrupts and enables the watchdog to reload an initial count value from WDG_LOAD to restart counting.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_RIS
RegisterGroup.description: a raw interrupt status register. It shows the raw interrupt status of the watchdog.

Member.name: wdogris
Member.description:
Raw interrupt status of the watchdog. When the count value is decreased to 0, this bit is set to 1.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_MIS
RegisterGroup.description: a masked interrupt status register. It shows the masked interrupt status ofthe watchdog.

Member.name: wdogmis
Member.description:
Masked interrupt status of the watchdog.
0: No interrupt is generated or the interrupt is masked.
1: An interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_LOCK
RegisterGroup.description: a lock register. It is used to control the write and read permission forthe watchdog registers.

Member.name: wdg_lock
Member.description:
Writing 0x1ACC_E551 to this register enables the write permission for all watchdog registers.
Writing any value but not 0x1ACC_E551 disables the write permission for all watchdog registers.
Reading this register returns the lock status but not the value written to this register.
0x0000_0000: The write access is available (unlocked).
0x0000_0001: The write operation is forbidden (locked).

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CTRL
RegisterGroup.description: an MMC control register.

Member.name: use_internal_dmac
Member.description:
Whether to transfer data by using the IDMAC
0: The CPU transfers data by using the slave interface.
1: The CPU transfers data by using the IDMAC.

Member.name: abort_read_data
Member.description:
Whether to abort the data transfer during data read
0: invalid
1: After transmitting a suspend command during data read, the software polls the card to check when suspend occurs.
After the suspend occurs, the software sets the bit to 1. This enables the data transfer state machine to be restored to idle state for the next block transfer.
After the state machine restores to the idle status, this bit is cleared automatically.

Member.name: send_irq_response
Member.description:
Interrupt response TX control
0: invalid
1: An interrupt request (IRQ) response is transmitted automatically.
After the response is transmitted, this bit is cleared automatically.
To wait for the interrupt generated by the MMC controller, the host transmits the CMD40 command and waits for the interrupt response from the MMC controller. If you do not want the host to keep in the interrupt wait state, set this bit to 1, and transmit the CMD40 command to restore to the idle state.

Member.name: read_wait
Member.description:
Read wait control
0: disabled
1: enabled
This bit is valid only for the SDIO card that supports the read wait function.

Member.name: dma_enable
Member.description:
Reserved
The system uses the IDMAC.

Member.name: int_enable
Member.description:
Global interrupt enable
0: disabled
1: enabled
The interrupt output is valid only when this bit is valid and the interrupt source is enabled.

Member.name: dma_reset
Member.description:
Soft reset control for the IDMAC
0: invalid
1: reset the internal DMA interface
This bit is automatically reset after two AHB clock cycles.

Member.name: fifo_reset
Member.description:
Soft reset control for the internal FIFO
0: invalid
1: reset the FIFO pointer
This bit is reset automatically after the reset operation is complete.

Member.name: controller_reset
Member.description:
Soft reset control for the controller
0: invalid
1: reset the MMC/SD/SDIO host module

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_PWREN
RegisterGroup.description: a Power_en control register.

Member.name: power_enable
Member.description:
Power control
0: power off
1: power on
This value is used to drive the SDIO_CARD_POWER_EN pin.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CLKDIV
RegisterGroup.description: a clock divider register that shows the ratio of the frequency of the moduleoutput clock to the frequency of the input clock. For example, if the module input clock is 40MHz and the register value is set to 1, the output clock is 20 MHz. The clock divider is 2 x N.If the value of N is 0x0, it indicates no frequency division (2 x 0 = 0); if the value of N is 0x1,the frequency is divided by 2; if the value of N is 0xFF, the frequency is divided by 510.

Member.name: clk_divider0
Member.description: Clock divider 0. The clock divider is 2 x N. If the value of N is 0, it indicates no frequency division; if the value of N is 0x1, the frequency is divided by 2; if the value of N is 0xFF, the frequency is divided by 510.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CLKSRC
RegisterGroup.description: a clock source select register of the SD card.

Member.name: clk_source
Member.description: This bit must be set to 0.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CLKENA
RegisterGroup.description: a clock enable register.

Member.name: cclk_low_power
Member.description:
Card low-power control for disabling the card clock
0: non lower-power mode
1: low-power mode
When the card is idle, the card clock is disabled. This function is used only for the MMC and SD card, because the card clock of the SDIO card must be retained for detecting interrupts.

Member.name: cclk_enable
Member.description:
Card clock enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_TMOUT
RegisterGroup.description: a timeout register.

Member.name: data_timeout
Member.description: Timeout period for the data transfer of the card, in unit of the mmc_clk cycle of the card. The timeout is also the data starvation timeout of the CPU.

Member.name: response_timeout
Member.description: Response timeout period, in unit of the mmc_clk cycle of the card

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CTYPE
RegisterGroup.description: a card type register.

Member.name: card_width_0
Member.description:
Card bus width
0: non-8-bit mode
1: 8-bit mode
The details are as follows:
If bit[16] is 1, the bus width of the card is set to 8-bit mode, and the value of bit[0] is ignored.
If bit[16] is 0, the bus width of the card is set to 1-bit mode or 4-bit mode. In this case, the bus width depends on the value of bit[0].

Member.name: card_width_1
Member.description:
Card bus width
0: 1-bit mode
1: 4-bit mode

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_BLKSIZ
RegisterGroup.description: a block size configuration register.

Member.name: block_size
Member.description: Block size. The initial size of each block is 512 bytes.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_BYTCNT
RegisterGroup.description: a block transfer count register.

Member.name: byte_count
Member.description:
Number of transferred bytes. The number must be an integral multiple of the block size.
If data is not transferred by block, this register must be set to 0. In this case, the software needs to transmit a stop or an abort command to control the data transfer.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_INTMASK
RegisterGroup.description: an interrupt mask register.

Member.name: sdio_int_mask
Member.description:
SDIO interrupt mask
0: masked
1: enabled

Member.name: int_mask
Member.description:
Interrupt mask
0: masked
1: enabled
The definition of each bit is as follows:
Bit[15]: End-bit error (read)/Write no CRC (EBE)
Bit[14]: Auto command done (ACD)
Bit[13]: Start bit error(SBE)/Busy complete interrupt(BCI)
Bit[12]: Hardware locked write error (HLE)
Bit[11]: FIFO underrun/overrun error (FRUN)
Bit[10]: Data starvation by host timeout(HTO)/Volt_switch_int
Bit[9]: Data read timeout (DTO)
Bit[8]: Response timeout (RTO)
Bit[7]: Data CRC error (DCRC)
Bit[6]: Response CRC error (RCRC)
Bit[5]: Receive FIFO data request (RXDR)
Bit[4]: Transmit FIFO data request (TXDR)
Bit[3]: Data transfer over (DTO)
Bit[2]: Command done (CD)
Bit[1]: Response error (RE)
Bit[0]: Card detect (CD)

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CMDARG
RegisterGroup.description: a command parameter register.

Member.name: cmd_arg
Member.description: This field configures the command parameters transferred to the card. Command parameters are related to the protocol, and each command corresponds to a command parameter.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CMD
RegisterGroup.description: a command register.

Member.name: start_cmd
Member.description:
Start control
0: Do not start.
1: Start a command. After the command is sent to the card interface unit (CIU), this bit is cleared.
The CPU does not allow this register to be modified. Otherwise, an HLE interrupt is generated.
After sending a command, the CPU queries this bit, and then sends the next command when the value of this bit changes to 0.

Member.name: use_hold_reg
Member.description:
Use Hold register
0: CMD and DATA sent to card bypassing Hold register
1: CMD and DATA sent to card through Hold register

Member.name: volt_switch
Member.description:
Voltage switching enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: boot_mode
Member.description:
Boot mode
0: forcible boot mode
1: alternative boot mode

Member.name: disable_boot
Member.description:
Boot disable
If the software enables this bit and the Start_cmd bit at the same time, the controller aborts the boot operation.
The Enable_boot and Disable_boot bits cannot be enabled at the same time.

Member.name: expect_boot_ack
Member.description:
Boot response enable
If the software enables this bit and the Enable_boot bit at the same time, the controller detects the boot response signal, that is, the "0-1-0" sequence.

Member.name: enable_boot
Member.description:
Boot enable
This bit is available only when the boot mode is the forcible boot mode. If the software enables this bit and the Start_cmd bit at the same time, the controller pulls down the CMD signal to start the boot process.
The Enable_boot and Disable_boot bits cannot be enabled at the same time.

Member.name: update_clock_registes_only
Member.description:
Automatic update
0: The normal command sequence is used. That is, the values of MMC_CMD, MMC_CMDARG, MMC_TMOUT, MMC_CTYPE, MMC_BLKSIZ, and MMC_BYTCNT are transferred from the BIU to the CIU. The CIU uses the new values of registers when running new commands.
1: No command is sent, and only the clock register values in the card clock domain are updated. The values of MMC_CLKDIV, MMC_CLKSRC, and MMC_CLKENA are transferred to the card clock domain.
The card clock can be changed (frequency change and clock enable) even no command is transmitted.
Each time the card clock is changed, this bit needs to be set to 1. In this case, no command is transmitted to the card, and no CD interrupt is generated.

Member.name: card_number
Member.description: Sequence number of the card that is being used

Member.name: send_initialization
Member.description:
Whether to transmit the initialization sequence
0: Do not send the initialization sequence before sending the Send_initialization command (high level in 80 clock cycles).
1: Send the initialization sequence before transmitting the Send_initialization command.
When a card is powered on, the initialization sequence must be sent first for initialization. That is, this bit needs to be set to 1.

Member.name: stop_abort_cmd
Member.description:
Whether to send the stop/abort command when data is being transferred in open-ended mode or in fixed length mode
0: Do not send the stop/abort command.
1: Send the stop/abort command to stop the current data transfer.

Member.name: wait_prvdata_complete
Member.description:
Whether to send a command immediately
0: Send a command immediately even though the previous data transfer is not complete.
1: Send a command only when the previous data transfer is complete.
The typical value is 0. If this bit is set to 0, the transfer status can be read during data transfer, and the transfer can be stopped.

Member.name: send_auto_stop
Member.description:
Whether to send the stop command
0: Do not send the stop command after data transfer.
1: Send the stop command after data transfer.
In non-data transfer mode, this bit is ignored.

Member.name: transfer_mode
Member.description:
Transfer mode
0: block transfer mode
1: stream transfer mode
In non-data transfer mode, this bit is ignored.

Member.name: read_write
Member.description:
Read/Write control
0: Read data from the card.
1: Write data to the card.
In non-data transfer mode, this bit is ignored.

Member.name: data_transfer_expected
Member.description:
Data transfer indicator
0: No data is output from the card.
1: Data is output from the card.

Member.name: check_response_crc
Member.description:
Whether to perform the CRC check
0: Do not check the CRC response.
1: Check the CRC response.
No valid CRC is returned when some commands are responded. To prevent the host from performing CRC, the software needs to disable this function based on related commands.

Member.name: response_length
Member.description:
Response length
0: Short responses are output from the card.
1: Long responses are output from the card.
The length of a long response is 128 bits, and the length of a short response is 32 bits.

Member.name: response_expect
Member.description:
Whether there is response
0: No response is output from the card.
1: Responses are output from the card.

Member.name: cmd_index
Member.description: Command ID

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_RESP0
RegisterGroup.description: response register 0.

Member.name: response0
Member.description: Bit[31:0] of a response

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_RESP1
RegisterGroup.description: response register 1.

Member.name: response1
Member.description:
Bit[63:32] of a long response
After the CIU sends an auto-stop command, the corresponding response is stored in this register, and the response to the previous command is still stored in MMC_RESP0.
The auto-stop command is available only during data transfer, and the corresponding response is always a short response.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_RESP2
RegisterGroup.description: response register 2.

Member.name: response2
Member.description: Bit[95:64] of a long response

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_RESP3
RegisterGroup.description: response register 3.

Member.name: response3
Member.description: Bit[127:96] of a long response

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_MINTSTS
RegisterGroup.description: a masked interrupt status register.

Member.name: sdio_interrupt
Member.description:
SDIO interrupt mask status
The SDIO interrupt is valid only when MMC_INTMASK [sdio_int_mask] is enabled.
0: No SDIO interrupt is output from the card.
1: An SDIO interrupt is output from the card.

Member.name: int_status
Member.description:
Status of each interrupt
Bit[15]: End-bit error(read)/write no CRC(EBE)
Bit[14]: Auto command done(ACD)

Bit[10]: Data starvation by host timeout(HTO)/Volt_switch_int

Bit[8]: Response timeout(RTO)

Bit[6]: Response CRC error(RCRC)
Bit[5]: Receive FIFO data request(RXDR)
Bit[4]: Transmit FIFO data request(TXDR)

Bit[1]: Response error(RE)

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_RINTSTS

Member.name: sdio_interrupt
Member.description:
Raw SDIO interrupt status

The value of the interrupt status bit is independent of the interrupt mask status.

Member.name: int_status
Member.description:
Raw status of each interrupt Writing 1 clears the bits, and writing 0 has no effect. The value of the interrupt status bit is independent of the interrupt mask status.
Bit[15]: End-bit error (read)/write no CRC (EBE)
Bit[14]: Auto command done (ACD)
Bit[13]: Start bit error(SBE)/Busy complete interrupt(BCI)

Bit[8]: Response timeout (RTO)/Boot Ack Received(BAR)
Bit[7]: Data CRC error (DCRC)
Bit[6]: Response CRC error (RCRC)
Bit[5]: Receive FIFO data request (RXDR)
Bit[4]: Transmit FIFO data request (TXDR)
Bit[3]: Data transfer over (DTO)
Bit[2]: Command done (CD)
Bit[1]: Response error (RE)
Bit[0]: Card detect (CD)

RegisterGroup.description: a FIFO threshold register.

Member.name: rx_wmark
Member.description:
FIFO threshold watermark level during data read. If the data amount in the FIFO is above the threshold, a DMA request is enabled. After a data transfer, a DMA request is raised for transferring the remaining data no matter whether the threshold is reached.
In non-DMA mode, the RXDR interrupt is enabled. If the data amount in the FIFO is not above the threshold after a data transfer, no interrupt is generated. In this case, the software needs to read the remaining data by querying the DTD interrupt.
If a data transfer is complete in DMA mode, the DMA raises a single transfer request to read data until the DTD interrupt is generated even though the remaining data amount is below the threshold.
Restriction: RX_WMark FIFO_DEPTH – 2
Recommendation: (FIFO_DEPTH/2) – 1

Member.name: tx_wmark
Member.description:
FIFO threshold watermark level during data transmit. If the data amount in the FIFO is below the threshold, a DMA request is enabled. After a data transfer, a DMA request is raised for transferring the remaining data no matter whether the threshold is reached.
In non-DMA mode, the RXDR interrupt is enabled. If the data amount in the FIFO is not above the threshold after a data transfer, no interrupt is generated. In this case, the software needs to read the remaining data by querying the DTD interrupt.
If a data transfer is complete in DMA mode, the DMA raises a single transfer request to read data until the DTD interrupt is generated even though the remaining data amount is below the threshold.
Restriction: TX_WMark FIFO_DEPTH – 2
Recommendation: (FIFO_DEPTH/2) – 1

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CDETECT

Member.name: card_detect_n

Card detection signal
The value depends on the SDIO_CARD_DETECT pin.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_WRTPRT

Member.name: write_protect

Card write protection signal
The value depends on the SDIO_CWPR pin.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_TCBCNT
RegisterGroup.description: a count register of bytes transmitted to the card.

Member.name: trans_card_byte_count
Member.description:
Count of bytes transmitted from the CIU to the card
When this register is accessed through a 32-bit AHB, the 32-bit data needs to be read at a time. This avoids the read-coherency error.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_TBBCNT
RegisterGroup.description: a count register of bytes transmitted from the BIU FIFO.

Member.name: trans_fifo_byte_count
Member.description:
Count of bytes transferred between the CPU/DMA and BIU FIFO
When this register is accessed through a 32-bit AHB, the 32-bit data needs to be read at a time. This avoids the read-coherency error.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_BMOD
RegisterGroup.description: a bus mode register.

Member.name: pbl
Member.description:
Length of the IDMAC burst transfer
000: 1
001: 4
010: 8
011: 16
1xx: reserved

Member.name: de
Member.description:
IDMAC enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: dsl
Member.description: Span between two descriptors, that is, number of words between two non-linked descriptors. This field is valid only for the dual-buffer descriptors.

Member.name: fb
Member.description:
Fixed burst length type
0: single and INCR burst types
1: single, INCR4, INCR8, and INCR16 burst types

Member.name: swr
Member.description:
Soft reset control for the internal register of the IDMAC
0: not reset
1: reset After reset, this bit is automatically cleared one clock cycle later.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_PLDMND
RegisterGroup.description: a poll demand register.

Member.name: pd
Member.description: If DES0[OWN] is 0, the IDMAC enters the suspend state. The CPU can write any value to this register to enable the IDMAC to obtain descriptors again.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_DBADDR
RegisterGroup.description: a base address register of the descriptor linked list.

Member.name: sdl
Member.description: Start address for the descriptor linked list, that is, the base address of the first descriptor

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_IDSTS
RegisterGroup.description: an IDMAC status register.

Member.name: fsm
Member.description:
Current state of the IDMAC state machine
0x0: DMA_IDLE
0x1: DMA_SUSPEND
0x2: DESC_RD
0x3: DESC_CHK
0x4: DMA_RD_REQ_WAIT
0x5: DMA_WR_REQ_WAIT
0x6: DMA_RD
0x7: DMA_WR
0x8: DESC_CLOSE
Others: reserved
This bit is read-only.

Member.name: eb
Member.description:
Bus error type
001: The TX operation is aborted.
010: The RX operation is aborted.
Other values: reserved

Member.name: ais
Member.description: Abnormal total interrupt. The value of this bit is obtained after the values of FBE, DE, and CES bits are ORed. Writing 1 clears this bit.

Member.name: nis
Member.description: Normal total interrupt. The value of this bit is obtained after the values of the TI and RI bits are ORed. Writing 1 clears this bit.

Member.name: ces
Member.description: Card error indicator. This bit indicates the card status when data is being received.

Member.name: du
Member.description: Descriptor invalid interrupt. When DES0[OWN] is 0, this bit is set to 1. Writing 1 clears this bit.

Member.name: fbe
Member.description: Fatal bus error interrupt. If this bit is set to 1, the IDMAC stops all accesses through the bus. Writing 1 clears this bit.

Member.name: ri
Member.description: RX completion interrupt. This bit indicates that the data for a descriptor is received. Writing 1 clears this bit.

Member.name: ti
Member.description: TX completion interrupt. This bit indicates that a descriptor finishes transmitting data. Writing 1 clears this bit.

Member.name: ni

Normal interrupt enable

1: The TI/RI interrupts are enabled.

Member.name: ces
Member.description:
Card error interrupt enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: du
Member.description:
Descriptor invalid interrupt enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: fbe
Member.description:
Fatal bus error interrupt enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: ri
Member.description:
RX interrupt enable

1: enabled

Member.name: ti
Member.description:
TX interrupt enable

1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_CON
RegisterGroup.description: a NANDC configuration register.

Member.name: nf_mode
Member.description:
NAND flash interface type
00: async
01: toggle
10: ONFI 2.3
11: ONFI 3.0

Member.name: randomizer_en
Member.description:
Randomizer enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: ecc_type
Member.description:
ECC mode
0000: non-ECC
0001: 8-bit mode
0010: 13-bit mode
0011: 18-bit mode
0100: 24-bit mode
0101: 27-bit mode
0110: 32-bit mode
0111: 41-bit mode
1000: 48-bit mode
1001: 60-bit mode
1010: 72-bit mode
1011: 80-bit mode
Others: reserved
The reset value depends on the pin NFC_ECC_TYPE.

Member.name: rb_sel
Member.description:
Ready/busy signal select. It is valid when two external NAND flash memories (two CSs) are connected.
0: The NAND flash memories share a ready/busy signal.
1: The NAND flash memory each has its own ready/busy signal.
When only one NAND flash is connected, only cs0 and ready_busy 0 are used.

Member.name: cs_ctrl
Member.description:
CS control
0: When the NAND flash is busy, the CS signal is fixed at 0.
1: When the NAND flash is busy, the CS signal is set to 1.
This mode maps to the "cs don't care" mode of the NAND flash.

Member.name: bus_width
Member.description:
Data line width of the NAND flash
0: 8 bits
1: reserved
The reset value depends on the pin NFC_BUS_WIDE.

Member.name: page_size
Member.description:
Page size of the NAND flash
000: reserved
001: 2 KB
010: 4 KB
011: 8 KB
100: 16 KB
101: 32 KB
101~111: reserved
The reset value depends on the pin NFC_PAGE_SIZE.

Member.name: op_mode
Member.description:
Operating mode of the NANDC
0: boot mode
1: normal mode

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_PWIDTH
RegisterGroup.description: a read/write pulse width configuration register.

Member.name: rw_hcnt
Member.description:
High-level width of the read/write signal of the NAND flash
0x1–0xF: 2 to 16 clock cycles

Member.name: r_lcnt
Member.description:
Low-level width of the read signal of the NAND flash
0x2–0xF: 3 to 16 clock cycles

Member.name: w_lcnt
Member.description:
Low-level width of the write signal of the NAND flash
0x1–0xF: 2 to 16 clock cycles

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_OPIDLE
RegisterGroup.description: an operation interval configuration register.

Member.name: frb_wait
Member.description:
Several delay cycles later after a read/write command is sent, the ready signal is detected to check whether it becomes high.
Number of delay cycles = frb_wait x 8

Member.name: cmd1_wait
Member.description:
Number of wait cycles after command 1 is sent
0000–1111: 1 to 16 clock cycles

Member.name: addr_wait
Member.description:
Number of wait cycles after addresses are sent
0000–1111: configured values
Number of delay cycles = addr_wait x 8

Member.name: cmd2_wait
Member.description:
Number of wait cycles after command 2 is sent
0000–1111: 1 to 16 clock cycles

Member.name: wait_ready_wait
Member.description:
When a number of cycles are delayed after the ready signal of the NAND flash becomes high, a read signal is sent to read data.
Number of delay cycles = frb_idle x 8

Command 1 TX enable

1: enabled

Member.description:
NAND flash address write enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: write_data_en
Member.description:
NAND flash data write enable
Note: read_data_en and write_data_en cannot be 1 at the same time.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: cmd2_en
Member.description:
Command 2 TX enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.description:
Wait ready/busy high enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: read_data_en

NAND flash data read enable
Note: read_data_en and write_data_en cannot be 1 at the same time.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: read_status_en
Member.description:
When this bit is 1, the command 0x70 for reading the status is sent to the NAND flash and the status data is read from the NAND flash. After that, the returned status data is written to the nfc_status field of the NANDC status register.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_STATUS
RegisterGroup.description: a status register.

Member.name: nfc_randomizer_en
Member.description:
Randomizer enable of the NANDC
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: nfc_ecc_type
Member.description:
ECC information of the NANDC
The read value indicates the same as the value of ecc_type in the NFC_CON register.

Member.name: nf_status
Member.description:
NAND flash status data read from the NAND flash
This field is valid only when both NFC_OP[read_status] and NFC_STATUS[nfc_ready] are 1.

Member.name: nf1_ready
Member.description:
Status of the ready/busy signal of the NAND flash corresponding to CS 1
This bit is valid when multiple external flash memories are connected and they use independent ready_busy signals.
The reset value of this bit is 0 because multiple NAND flash memories share a ready/busy signal by default.

Member.name: nf0_ready
Member.description:
Status of the ready/busy signal of the NAND flash corresponding to CS 0
This bit is valid when multiple external flash memories are connected and they use independent ready_busy signals.
The reset value of this bit is 0 because multiple NAND flash memories share a ready/busy signal by default.

Member.name: nfc_ready
Member.description:
Current NANDC status
0: The controller is performing an operation.
1: The operation is complete and the controller is ready to receive the next command.
This bit is automatically cleared when the operation register is written to start the NANDC.

1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_INTS
RegisterGroup.description: an interrupt status register.

Member.name: dma_err
Member.description:
DMA transfer bus error interrupt
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: dma_done
Member.description:
DMA transfer completion interrupt
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: wr_lock_err
Member.description:
Locked address write interrupt
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: ahb_op_err
Member.description:
Interrupt generated when the CPU reads and writes to the NANDC buffer in the process of reading/writing data from/to the flash by the NANDC
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: err_invalid
Member.description:
Uncorrectable error interrupt
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in eight or more bits of the checked 1 KB data in 8-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 13 or more bits of the checked 1 KB data in 13-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 18 or more bits of the checked 1 KB data in 18-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 24 or more bits of the checked 1 KB data in 24-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 27 or more bits of the checked 1 KB data in 27-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 32 or more bits of the checked 1 KB data in 32-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 41 or more bits of the checked 1 KB data in 41-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 48 or more bits of the checked 1 KB data in 48-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 60 or more bits of the checked 1 KB data in 60-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 72 or more bits of the checked 1 KB data in 72-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 80 or more bits of the checked 1 KB data in 80-bit ECC mode.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: err_valid
Member.description:
Correctable error interrupt.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 1 to 8 bits of the checked 1 KB data in 8-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 1 to 13 bits of the checked 1 KB data in 13-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 1 to 18 bits of the checked 1 KB data in 18-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 1 to 24 bits of the checked 1 KB data in 24-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 1 to 27 bits of the checked 1 KB data in 27-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 1 to 32 bits of the checked 1 KB data in 32-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 1 to 41 bits of the checked 1 KB data in 41-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 1 to 48 bits of the checked 1 KB data in 48-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 1 to 60 bits of the checked 1 KB data in 60-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 1 to 72 bits of the checked 1 KB data in 72-bit ECC mode.
An interrupt is generated if errors occur in 1 to 80 bits of the checked 1 KB data in 80-bit ECC mode.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: cs1_done
Member.description:
Interrupt generated when the ready/busy signal corresponding to CS 1 changes from low to high
This bit is valid when two flash memories are connected and the two memories use separate ready_busy signals. Otherwise, this bit is fixed at 0.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: cs0_done
Member.description:
Interrupt generated when the ready/busy signal corresponding to CS 0 changes from low to high
This bit is valid when two flash memories are connected and the two memories use separate ready_busy signals. Otherwise, this bit is fixed at 0.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: op_done
Member.description:
Current NANDC operation completion interrupt
This bit is automatically cleared when the NFC_OP register is written.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: dma_wr_en
Member.description:
DMA read/write enable
0: read
1: write

Member.name: dma_start
Member.description:
DMA operation start
Writing 1 to this bit starts the DMA operation. The bit retains 1 until the DMA operation is complete. Writing 0 to this bit has no effect.
After the DMA operation is started, if 0 is returned when this bit is read, the DMA operation is complete.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_SEGMENT_ID
RegisterGroup.description: a data segment ID register for reading and writing to the NAND flashin DMA mode.

Member.name: segment_id
Member.description:
As the internal buffer stores only 8 KB data at a time, this bit indicates the 8 KB data segment that is being read or written when the flash memory page size is 16 KB or 32 KB.
00: The first 8 KB data segment is being read/written.
01: The second 8 KB data segment is being read/written.
10: The third 8 KB data segment is being read/written.
11: The fourth 8 KB data segment is being read/written.

Member.name: block_size

01: 128 pages

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_SYNC_TIMING

Member.name: t_cad
Member.description:
Delay period before nf_ale and nf_cle of the ONFI 2 component are pulled up
0x0–0xF: 1 to 16 clock cycles

Member.name: t_dqz
Member.description:
Interval between the time point when the DQS signal is invalid and the time point when the signal is transferred again for the ONFI 2 component
0x0–0xF: 1 to 16 clock cycles

Member.name: pre_rdqs
Member.description:
Leading time before the toggle read operation nf_re_n
0x0–0xF: 1 to 16 clock cycles
It must be greater than 40 ns.

Member.name: post_rdqs
Member.description:
Rear leading time after the toggle read operation nf_re_n. After the ONFI component reads data, the DQS signal is pulled down to the tristate time.
0x0–0xF: 1 to 16 clock cycles

Member.name: pre_wdqs
Member.description:
Leading time before the write operation nf_dqs
0x0–0xF: 1 to 16 clock cycles
It must be greater than 40 ns.

Member.name: post_wdqs
Member.description:
Rear leading time after the read operation nf_dqs
0x0–0xF: 1 to 16 clock cycles

Member.name: rw_psth
Member.description:
Interval between the time point when the DQS signal is invalid and the time point when the nf_ce_n signal is invalid for the toggle read/write operation
0x0–0xF: 1 to 16 clock cycles

RegisterGroup.name: IR_EN
RegisterGroup.description: an IR RX enable control register.CAUTIONBefore configuring other registers, set IR_EN[ir_en] to 1 by using software. Otherwise,configuring other registers has no effect. When IR_EN[ir_en] is 0, other registers are read-only and the read values are their reset values.

Member.name: ir_en
Member.description:
IR RX enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: IR_CFG
RegisterGroup.description:
an IR configuration register.CAUTIONBefore setting this register, ensure that IR_BUSY[ir_busy] is set to 0 and IR_EN[ir_en] is setto 1. Otherwise, the original value is retained after setting.The reference clock frequency supported by the IR module ranges from 1 MHz to 128 MHz.The following is mapping between the frequency and the clock divider ir_freq:
  • When the reference clock frequency is 1 MHz, ir_freq must be set to 0x00.
  • If the reference clock frequency is 128 MHz, ir_freq must be set to 0x7F.
  • If the reference clock frequency is 128 MHz, ir_freq must be set to 0x7F.When the frequency of the IR reference clock is not an integer ranging from 1 MHz to 128MHz, the clock divider is selected based on the rounded reference clock frequency. Forexample, if the reference clock frequency is 12.1 MHz, the clock divider is 0x0B; if thereference clock frequency is 12.8 MHz, the clock divider is 0x0C.The following describes the relationship between the frequency offset and the count deviation.If the base frequency is f and the frequency variation is Df, the frequency offset ratio is Df/f. Ifthe count deviation of the counter is Dcnt, and the judge level width is s (in μs), the countdeviation Dcnt is calculated as follows: Dcnt = 0.1 x s x ratio. Therefore, when the clock hasfrequency offset, the valid range of the parameter value needs to be changed. If the frequencyincreases, the corresponding margin range is changed to [min + Dcnt, max + Dcnt]. Wheremin and max indicate the margins without frequency offset. If the frequency decreases, theoffset range is changed to [min ? Dcnt, max ? Dcnt]. Take the margin of the start bit in thelead code as an example. If the base frequency is 100 MHz, and the frequency increases by0.1 MHz, the ratio is 0.001 (0.1/100). If s is 9000 μs, Dcnt is calculated as follows: Dcnt = 0.1x 9000 x 0.001 = 1. In this case, the margin range of ir_leads must be changed to [0x033D,

Member.name: ir_max_level_width
Member.description:
Invalid when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0.
Maximum level width (in 10 μs) of a symbol when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1. This width identifies the end of a symbol stream.

Member.name: ir_format
Member.description:
Data code format when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0.
00: NEC with simple repeat code
01: TC9012 code
10: NEC with full repeat code
11: SONY code
For details about the mapping between code types and code families, see Table 11-6 to Table 11-8.
Symbol format when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1.
bit[15]: reserved
The definitions of bit[14] are as follows:
0: The symbol is from low to high, and the symbol stream ends at the high level.
1: The symbol is from high to low, and the symbol stream ends at the low level.

Member.name: ir_bits
Member.description:
Number of data bits in a frame when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0.
0x00–0x2F: correspond to bit 1 to bit 48 in a frame respectively
0x30?0x3F: reserved
If ir_bits is set to a value ranging from 0x30 to 0x3F by using software, the setting has no effect and the original value is retained.
Symbol RX interrupt threshold when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1.
Bit[13:8]: 0x0–0x3F. 0x0 indicates that an interrupt is reported when there is at least one symbol in the FIFO, 0x3F indicates that an interrupt is reported when there are at least 64 symbols in the FIFO, and so on.

Member.name: ir_mode
Member.description:
IR operating mode.
0: The decoded complete data frames are output.
1: Only the symbol width is output.

Member.name: ir_freq
Member.description:
Clock divider of the working clock.
0x00–0x7F: correspond to the clock divider 1–128 respectively

RegisterGroup.name: IR_LEADS
RegisterGroup.description:
a lead code start bit margin configuration register (valid only whenIR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0).CAUTIONBefore setting this register, ensure that IR_BUSY[ir_busy] is set to 0 and IR_EN[ir_en] is setto 1. Otherwise, the original value is retained after setting.The margin must be considered based on the typical value of the specific code type foraccurately determining the start bit of the lead code. For details about the typical values ofspecified code types, see the values of LEAD_S in Table 11-6 to Table 11-8.
  • For a pulse width whose typical value is greater than or equal to 400 (10 μs precision),the recommended margin is 8% of the typical value. For example, if the typical value ofLEAD_S for D6121 is 900, the value of cnt_leads_min is 0x33C (900 x 92% = 828), andthe value of cnt_leads_max is 0x3CC (900 x 108% = 972).
  • For a pulse width whose typical value is less than 400 (10 μs precision), therecommended margin is 20% of the typical value. For example, if the typical value ofLEAD_S for SONY-D7C5 is 240, the value of cnt_leads_min is 0xC0 (240 x 80% =192), and the value of cnt_leads_max is 0x120 (240 x 120% = 288).The basic configuration principles are as follows: cnt_leads_max is greater than or equal tocnt_leads_min, and cnt_leads_min is greater than cnt0_b_max and cnt1_b_max.

Member.name: cnt_leads_min
Member.description:
Minimum pulse width of the start bit of the lead code.
0x000?0x007: reserved

Member.name: cnt_leads_max
Member.description:
Maximum pulse width of the start bit of the lead code.
0x000?0x007: reserved

  • For the pulse width whose typical value is greater than or equal to 400 (10 μs precision),the recommended margin is 8% of the typical value.   • For a pulse width whose typical value is less than 400 (10 μs precision), therecommended margin is 20% of the typical value. For example, if the typical value ofLEAD_E for SONY-D7C5 is 60, the value of cnt_leade_min is 0x030 (60 x 80% = 48),and the value of cnt_leade_max is 0x048 (60 x 120% = 72).The basic configuration principle is as follows: cnt_leade_max is greater than or equal tocnt_leade_min.cnt_leade_min.

  • the value of cnt_sleade_max is 0x048 (60 x 120% = 72).The basic configuration principle is as follows: cnt_sleade_max is greater than or equal tocnt_sleade_min.

RegisterGroup.name: IR_DATAH
RegisterGroup.description: an upper 16-bit IR RX decoded data register (IR_CFG[ir_mode] = 0) orsymbol FIFO symbol count register (IR_CFG[ir_mode] = 1).The IR_DATAH register receives the upper 16 bits of the decoded data, whereas theIR_DATAL register receives the lower 32 bits of the decoded data. The specific data bitsdepend on the valid data bits in a frame in a specific code format. For details, see the validdata bits in Table 11-6 to Table 11-8.Data is stored in IR_DATAH and then IR_DATAL from MSB to LSB. That is, afterreserved. Software must read IR_DATAH and then IR_DATAL.When IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1, hardware receives all data bits without regardless of thedefinition of each data bit. Then software processes the data bits.

Member.name: ir_datah
Member.description:
Upper 16 bits of the decoded data received by the IR module when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0.
Number of symbols in the symbol FIFO when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1.
bit[15:7]: reserved
bit[6:0]: number of symbols in the symbol FIFO

RegisterGroup.name: IR_DATAL
RegisterGroup.description: a lower 32-bit IR RX decoded data register (IR_CFG[ir_mode] = 0) or IRreceived symbol width register (IR_CFG[ir_mode] = 1).

Member.name: ir_datal
Member.description:
Lower 32 bits of the decoded data received by the IR module when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0.
Width of the symbol received by the IR module when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1.
The following are the definitions of bit[31:16]:
When the symbol is low and then high, these bits indicate the high-level width (measured by 10 μs) of the symbol received by the IR module.
When the symbol is high and then low, these bits indicate the low-level width (measured by 10 μs) of the symbol received by the IR module.
The following are the definitions of bit[15:0]:
When the symbol is low and then high, these bits indicate the low-level width (measured by 10 μs) of the symbol received by the IR module.
When the symbol is high and then low, these bits indicate the high-level width (measured by 10 μs) of the symbol received by the IR module.

RegisterGroup.name: IR_INT_MASK
RegisterGroup.description:
an IR interrupt mask register.CAUTION
  • Before setting this register, ensure that IR_EN[ir_en] is set to 1. Otherwise, the originalvalue is retained after setting.
  • If all interrupts are masked, the IR wakeup function is unavailable.
  • When IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0, IR_INT_MASK bit[3:0] are valid; when IR_CFG[ir_mode]is 1, IR_INT_MASK bit[18:16] are valid.The following describes related interrupts:
  • RX data overrun interrupt
    • If the CPU does not fetch the current frame and the next frame is received, the nextframe overwrites the current frame, and a raw RX data overrun error interrupt is reported.
  • RX data frame format error interrupt
    • RX data frame format error interrupt If the received data frame is incomplete or incorrect data pulse width of the margin range,the reports of the raw receive frame format error interrupt request.
  • RX data frame interrupt
    • After a complete frame data is received, a raw RX data frame interrupt is reported.
  • Key release detection interrupt
    • For the NEC with simple repeat code and TC9012 code, if the start synchronous code isnot detected again within 160 ms after the previously detected start synchronous code, ora valid data frame but not a simple lead code is detected, a raw key release detectioninterrupt is reported. The key release detection interrupt is not supported for theNEC with full repeat code and the SONY code.
  • RX symbol overrun interrupt
    • If the symbol FIFO is full because the CPU does not fetch the data in a timely mannerand the subsequent symbol is received, a raw RX symbol overrun error interrupt isreported.
  • RX symbol interrupt
    • If a complete symbol is received and the number of symbols in the symbol FIFO isabove the threshold configured in IR_CFG[ir_bits], a raw RX symbol interrupt isreported.
  • Symbol timeout interrupt
    • If no new symbol interrupt is received during the period configured ininterrupt is reported.Hardware does not identify the interrupt priority. An interrupt is generated if one or moremasked interrupt sources are valid.

0: not masked
1: masked

Member.description:

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_DATA
RegisterGroup.description:
a GPIO data register. It is used to buffer the input or output data.When the corresponding bit of GPIO_DIR is configured as output, the values written toGPIO_DATA are sent to the corresponding pin (ensure that the configuration of pinmultiplexing is correct). If the bit is configured as input, the value of the corresponding inputpin is read.CAUTION
  • When the corresponding bits of GPIO_DIR are set to inputs, the pin values are returned ifthe read operations are valid. When the corresponding bits are set to outputs, the writtenvalues are returned if the read operations are valid.GPIO_DATA masks the read and write operations on bits by using PADDR[9:2]. The registercorresponds to 256 address spaces. PADDR[9:2] correspond to GPIO_DATA[7:0]respectively. When a PADDR bit is high, the corresponding bit can be read or written; whenthe corresponding bit is low, the read or write operation cannot be performed. See thefollowing instance:
  • If the address is 0x3FC (0b11_1111_1100), the operations on all the eight bits ofGPIO_DATA[7:0] are valid.
  • If the address is 0x200 (0b10_0000_0000), the operation on only GPIO_DATA[7] isvalid.

Member.name: gpio_data
Member.description: GPIO input data when the GPIO is configured as input or GPIO output data when the GPIO is configured as output. Each bit can be separately controlled. This register works with GPIO_DIR.

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_DIR
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO direction control register. It is used to configure the direction of eachGPIO pin.

Member.name: gpio_dir
Member.description:
GPIO direction control. Bit[7:0] correspond to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively. Each bit can be separately controlled.
0: input
1: output

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_IS
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO interrupt trigger mode register. It is used to configure the interrupt triggermode.

Member.name: gpio_is
Member.description:
GPIO interrupt trigger mode. Bit[7:0] correspond to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively. Each bit can be separately controlled.
0: edge-sensitive mode
1: level-sensitive mode

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_IBE
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO interrupt edge control register. It is used to configure the edge triggermode of each GPIO pin.

Member.name: gpio_ibe
Member.description:
GPIO interrupt edge control. Bit[7:0] correspond to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively. Each bit can be separately controlled.
0: single-edge-sensitive mode. GPIO_IEV controls whether the interrupt is rising-edge-sensitive or falling-edge-sensitive.
1: dual-edge-sensitive mode

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_IEV
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO interrupt event register. It is used to configure the interrupt trigger eventof a GPIO pin.

Member.name: gpio_iev
Member.description:
GPIO interrupt event. Bit[7:0] correspond to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively. Each bit can be separately controlled.
0: The interrupt is triggered at the falling edge or low level.
1: The interrupt is triggered at the rising edge or high level.

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_IE
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO interrupt mask register. It is used to mask GPIO interrupts.

Member.name: gpio_ie
Member.description:
GPIO interrupt mask. Bit[7:0] corresponds to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively. Each bit can be separately controlled.
0: masked
1: not masked

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_RIS
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO raw interrupt status register. It is used to query the raw interrupt statusof each GPIO pin.

Member.name: gpio_ris
Member.description:
GPIO raw interrupt status. Bit[7:0] corresponds to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively, indicating the unmasked interrupt status. This status is not under the mask control of the GPIO_IE register.
1: An interrupt is generated.
0: No interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_MIS
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO masked interrupt status register. It is used to query the masked interruptstatus of each GPIO pin.

Member.name: gpio_mis
Member.description:
GPIO masked interrupt status. Bit[7:0] corresponds to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively, indicating the masked interrupt status. This status is under the mask control of the GPIO_IE register.
0: The interrupt is invalid.
1: The interrupt is valid.

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_IC
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO interrupt clear register. It is used to clear the GPIO_RIS and GPIO_MISregisters and interrupts generated by GPIO pins.

Member.name: gpio_ic
Member.description:
GPIO interrupt clear. Bit[7:0] corresponds to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively. Each bit can be separately controlled.
0: no effect
1: interrupt cleared

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_RESERVED
RegisterGroup.description: a reserved GPIO register. It must be configured as required.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: This field must be set to 0x00.

RegisterGroup.name: SATA_GHC_GHC
RegisterGroup.description: a global control register.

Member.name: ahci_en
Member.description: Fixed at 1, indicating that software can interact with the controller by using only the AHCI mechanism.

Member.name: int_enable
Member.description:
Controller interrupt enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: hba_rst
Member.description:
Soft reset control for the controller.
0: not reset
1: reset
Writing 1 resets the controller and this bit is cleared after reset; writing 0 has no effect. In addition, reset has no effect on the registers SATA_GHC_BOHC, SATA_PORT_FB, and SATA_PORT_CLB.
